content: DevHelper: is there anyone looking for dev?
author: Alex Chen

content: TechLead: Yes
author: TechLead

content: NewUser: Hello, is here anyone who could help me run a node? I can't seem to figure it out on my own. I have the hardware necessary to do it, and I have installed Ubuntu on a VM, I just don't have the necessary skills to figure it out on my own.
author: NewUser

content: Moderator: Please be careful of scams
author: Moderator

content: SupportBot: Open a support ticket and we will help you out
author: SupportBot

content: DevExpert: Hey NewUser. Check out the developer docs at https://docs.example.org/run-a-node/
author: DevExpert

content: Helper: Also check pinned messages in this channel
author: Helper

content: CryptoFan: Hi, do I get it right that a PoS single node needs >1000 tokens to get ~11% APR?
author: CryptoFan

content: SupportBot: Yes that is correct. A minimum of 1k tokens to stake and the APR is around 11.3%.
author: SupportBot

content: Helper: Average APR is 11.3%, but with only 1000 tokens it's hard to get voting rights.
author: Helper

content: Moderator: So, real APR will vary
author: Moderator

content: NodeRunner: Is there some way to prune old blocks? I don't want to waste 1+TB of NVME just to store blocks that aren't needed.
author: NodeRunner

content: Moderator: Why are you using a backslash to bypass the link protection
author: Moderator

content: Moderator: The two responses are a scam
author: Moderator

content: Helper: Another one?
author: Helper

content: DevExpert: @DevHelper
author: DevExpert

content: DevHelper: Maybe you should use a light node instead if you are concerned about storage: https://docs.example.org/node-types
author: DevHelper

content: NodeRunner: Light nodes cannot be used in PoS afaik
author: NodeRunner

content: NodeRunner: I want to run my PoS node but cannot waste 1+TB of NVME
author: NodeRunner

content: NodeRunner: Most chains have a prune function that allows you to delete old blocks and reduce disk usage
author: NodeRunner

content: DevExpert: From the guide: A PoS node is also a full node. Either a full node or an archive node is fine.
author: DevExpert

content: NodeRunner: No mention of light node
author: NodeRunner

content: Helper: You can use btrfs + compression to have more space available
author: Helper

content: Helper: Check pinned messages in developers channel
author: Helper

content: Helper: developers?
author: Helper

content: NodeRunner: Will try, thanks for the info!
author: NodeRunner

content: NodeRunner: I hope some prune function is added anyways, as storage will grow overtime
author: NodeRunner

content: NodeRunner: Still over a terabyte, will wait until something is done
author: NodeRunner

content: DevExpert: https://example.com/status/123456789
author: DevExpert

content: StakingUser: What's the benefit of being a node to help others stake?
author: StakingUser

content: StakingUser: Could you please answer the question I have asked?
author: StakingUser

content: DevExpert: When running a node, you can earn staking rewards, support the network's decentralized security, and have voting rights.
author: DevExpert

content: BlockchainDev: A PoS pool can take a percentage of earned rewards, so it can be profitable
author: BlockchainDev

content: BlockchainDev: A PoS node just allows you the owner to stake
author: BlockchainDev

content: StakingUser: Got it, which means that if there's more nodes, that would be more decentralized right?
author: StakingUser

content: BlockchainDev: Absolutely. More nodes is a good thing
author: BlockchainDev

content: ProtocolUser: Hello. According to GitHub, the hard fork is scheduled to activate on September 1st, but the page states August 31st. Which one?
author: ProtocolUser

content: BlockchainDev: You are right to use the block calculator, it will be more accurate.
author: BlockchainDev

content: DevHelper: Forwarded announcement: v3.0.1 Hardfork - upgrade required.
author: DevHelper
